required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Does Bicarbonate in Addition to Theophylline Reduce CIN?
clinical_study.official_title: Does Bicarbonate in Addition to Theophylline Reduce Contrast Induced Nephropathy Compared to Sodium Chloride?

brief_summary.textblock:
Contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) is the third most frequent cause of hospital-acquired acute renal failure. Different regimes in the prophylaxis of CIN have been investigated in the last years. Recent Meta-analysis show a reduced incidence of CIN when theophylline is administered to the patients especially in patients with already existing renal impairment. Furthermore hydration with bicarbonate seems to to be superior to hydration with sodium chloride alone. The combination of the two prophylaxis has not been investigated yet.
Aim of this prospective randomized trial is to investigate the effect of hydration with sodium bicarbonate compared to saline in addition to theophylline prophylaxis which all patients receive.

primary_outcome.description: Raise in serum creatinine of ≥25% or ≥0.5 mg/dl

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of serum creatinine levels over time
Change of creatinine clearance over time
Incidence of patients with need for dialysis
secondary_outcome.description: The patients medical record was reviewed to determine whether dialysis was performed within 30 days after contrast media application.

arm_group.description: Hydration with bicarbonate in addition to theophylline
Hydration with sodium chloride in addition to theophylline

intervention.intervention_name: Hydration with bicarbonate in addition to theophylline
intervention.description: 0.154-molar sodium bicarbonate; 3 ml per kg bodyweight (maximum 330 ml) one hour before contrast exposure; additionally 200 mg theophylline as a short infusion; after contrast application hydration with another 1 ml per kg bodyweight per hour (maximum 110 ml per hour) for 6 hours

intervention.intervention_name: Hydration with sodium chloride in addition to theophylline
intervention.description: 0.9% sodium chloride; 3 ml per kg bodyweight (maximum 330 ml) one hour before contrast exposure; additionally 200 mg theophylline as a short infusion; after contrast application hydration with another 1 ml per kg bodyweight per hour (maximum 110 ml per hour) for 6 hours

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
Increased risk for contrast induced nephropathy defined as:
- Serum creatinine level ≥ 1.1 mg/dl OR
- Serum creatinine level ≥ 0.8 mg/dl plus an additional risk factor like diabetes mellitus, renal failure in past medical history or nephrotoxic medication (aminoglycoside, vancomycin, amphotericin B, diuretic)
Exclusion Criteria:
- pre-existing renal replacement therapy
- unstable serum creatinine levels (difference of more than ±0.4 mg/dl within 3 days before contrast application)
- contraindications for theophylline or sodium bicarbonate (allergies, tachycardia, alkalosis, hypokalemia)
- additional interventions that might influence renal function

overall_official.affiliation: 2. Medizinische Klinik, Klinikum rechts der Isar der Technischen Universität München
